In the case of the sort method, let me say this: there are two
possibilities: you wrote the sort methods or you didn't.

Suppose you wrote the sort methods. That means that they have tests,
and damn good ones. As a result, a method like this can't break on its
own:

if myCollection.size < 20
    myCollection.sortWith(SortAlgorithms.bubbleSort)
else if myCollection.size < 100
    myCollection.sortWith(SortAlgorithms.quickSort)
else
    myCollection.sortWith(SortAlgorithms.mergeSort)
end

This method does nothing except double-dispatch on myCollection, where
I assume the sortWith method is defined like this:

def Collection.sortWith(sortAlgorithm)
    sortAlgorithm.sortInPlace(myCollection)
end

This method is clearly too thin to break *on its own*. It can only
break if one of the SortAlgorithms is broken. As a result, don't test
this method. If you need to, test Collection.size, but otherwise,
there's nothing to gain from testing this method in particular.
99.9999% of the time, the SortAlgorithms will work and you can't gain
any more confidence by testing such simple use of the SortAlgorithms.

Of course, you may not have written the Sort Algorithms. In that case,
you have a choice: assume they work, or write what I'd call
IDontTrustYou tests. These are tests of a third-party API that you
don't trust to work. Write tests that use representative samples of
input you expect to sort. Now that you know they work (or that they
don't), there is still nothing more to gain by testing the method up
top in this message. It's too thin to really break.

Either way, I'm suggesting you test the code that does the *real* work
and not one-liners that simply call other code. (Notice that the if
construct is essentially a one-liner calling three other one-liners.)
When in doubt, try to dig down to find the class that does the
interesting stuff, and test *that* class the way you'd test the current
class.

Here's the acid test: ask yourself, can this method break on its own?
In other words: is it possible that everything this method calls can
work, while this method fails? What would have to happen for this
method to break? If the logic of the current method is so simple that
it doesn't end up on your list of ways the method could break, then
test the stuff your method calls, instead. This strategy reduces test
coupling and makes your code more refactoring-friendly without reducing
(by much) your confidence in it.

>> From: Berin Loritsch [mailto:bloritsch@...]

>> * NEVER assume anything about the internals.  Any code that uses
>>   assumptions _*will*_ break.
>
>Note that using knowledge of internals of the code does not
necessarily 
>make any assumptions about the code or make the tests breakable by
>changing the implementation.
> 
>Consider the recent example of the sort method that selects a
different 
>algorithm depending on the size of the input.  
>
>A test that is written to exercise both branches is written with
knowledge 
>of the implementation.  However, it doesn't make any assumptions about
>the implementation that will break anything.  
>
>(True, it assumes that there is a breakpoint between 19 and 20 that is
>worth testing, and that assumption can be invalidated by a different
>implementation, but nothing breaks except maybe the efficiency of
